title: 107_hr504
content: The Act may be cited as the "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001". The purpose of the Act is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to assist communities and health care providers in developing integrated health care delivery systems for uninsured and underinsured individuals, through coordination of services, infrastructure development, and provision of new Federal resources. The Act aims to assist communities and health care providers in developing integrated health care delivery systems for uninsured and underinsured individuals, through coordination of services, infrastructure development, and provision of new Federal resources without supplanting funding for existing programs supporting low-income populations. SEC. 3. CREATION OF COMMUNITY ACCESS PROGRAM. This section amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a new subpart for the Community Access Program, providing grants to enhance services for the uninsured and underinsured. The Secretary may grant funds to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured communities, expanding services and improving coordination among providers. Eligible entities include public or nonprofit entities like Federally qualified health centers and hospitals meeting specific criteria. Entities eligible for grants to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured communities include hospitals, public health departments, and consortia of providers focused on providing coordinated health care services for specific community groups. Entities eligible for grants to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured communities must include all health care providers serving the community, with preference given to providers identified in paragraph (1). Applications must meet specific criteria, such as serving special population groups and may include other health care providers and related agencies. Entities eligible for grants to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured communities must include all health care providers serving the community, with preference given to providers identified in paragraph (1). Applications for grants must define the target community and identify participating providers and their contributions to care for uninsured and underinsured individuals. The grant application must describe the activities proposed by the consortium to further the purposes of the grant, demonstrate the ability to involve providers serving uninsured and underinsured individuals, and develop coordinated systems of care for a broad range of services. The grant application must demonstrate community involvement, ensure enrollment in public insurance programs, leverage other funding sources for sustainability, and include a plan for evaluation of activities. The grant application must demonstrate fiscal responsibility, evaluation plans, and commitment to serving the community without regard to ability to pay. Priority may be given to applicants who meet these criteria. The Secretary may prioritize grant applicants with consortiums including public hospitals, Federally qualified health centers, and providers serving uninsured individuals. Applicants identifying communities with high uninsured rates and showing evidence of expanding programs may also receive priority. The Secretary may prioritize grant applicants with consortiums including public hospitals, Federally qualified health centers, and providers serving uninsured individuals. Applicants must show evidence of expanding programs to improve coordination between health care providers and social service providers, utilize non-Federal contributions, and collaborate with State and local governments. The Secretary may prioritize grant applicants with consortiums including public hospitals, Federally qualified health centers, and providers serving uninsured individuals. Applicants must show evidence of expanding programs to improve coordination between health care providers and social service providers, utilize non-Federal contributions, and collaborate with State and local governments. Grantees can use funds for direct expenses associated with planning, developing, and operating a health care delivery system that provides a broad range of services. The grant funds can be used for a variety of purposes, including increasing outreach activities, improving case management, and coordinating transportation to healthcare facilities within an integrated delivery system. The grant funds can be used for various purposes such as improving coordination of transportation to health care facilities, developing provider networks, recruiting and training personnel, acquiring technology, closing gaps in services, improving provider communication, and other activities to increase access to the uninsured. No more than 15% of the funds can be used for direct patient care. The grant funds can be used for various purposes to increase access to the uninsured, with a limit of 15% for direct patient care. The Secretary may use up to 3% of funds for national program purposes. Maintenance of effort is required for grant recipients. The Secretary may award a grant under this section only if the recipient and participating providers agree to maintain their non-Federal fund expenditures at or above the previous year's level. Recipients must report annually on goal progress and provide additional information as requested. Grant renewal is contingent on reasonable progress towards stated goals. The Secretary may award grants if the consortium shows progress in meeting grant goals. Entities must undergo annual financial audits. The Secretary can provide technical assistance. $250,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for 2003-2006.
